Award.AwardTitle: Molecular-scale Interactions at the Peptide-mineral Interface
Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT
CHE-0613972
De Stasio Gilbert/Wisconsin - Madison

Biomineralization is the production of minerals by living organisms. The structure and formation of natural biominerals are controlled at the molecular scale by proteins, but most aspects of key organic-inorganic interactions remain unclear. With support from the Analytical and Surface Chemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry and the Biomaterials Program in the Division of Material Research, Gelsomina "Pupa" De Stasio Gilbert and her group in the University of Wisconsin-Madison Department of Physics are employing and developing spectroscopic methods to study molecular-scale interactions at the interfaces between peptides or proteins on one hand, and minerals or their precursor nanoparticles on the other. This will reveal how mineral structure and protein conformation influence one another, and how they evolve together during biomineralization. In particular, they focus on the interactions between peptides and calcium phosphate and calcium carbonate, which are relevant to the early steps in bone, teeth and shell formation.

Both graduate and undergraduate students are involved in the proposed experiments, and are assisting with preparation of biomineralization instructional materials for college and high school students. These materials will integrate the research results acquired by the students themselves, thereby integrating research, teaching and learning. Students will also invent and prepare demonstration stands and hands-on experiences on biomineralization for the broader community at the UW Synchrotron Radiation Center annual Open House, which hosts more than 200 people from the general public once a year, and for the "Microscopy of Life" course, which the PI teaches every spring (40 graduate and undergraduate students from 8 departments). Research in biomineralization is a multidisciplinary field, including chemistry, physics, biology, and materials science. The impact of the proposed experiments, therefore, will reach far beyond the boundaries of chemistry and physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Thanks to this grant we discovered how proteins interact with crystals to form mollusk shells. To verify our discoveries we tested the ideas in the laboratory, and we successfully made a small synthetic protein made of only 30-amino acids “template” the formation of aragonite in solution. Without this small protein only calcite (CaCO3) forms from the solution, but when adding the protein aragonite (also CaCO3) forms. In addition, the structure is “lamellar”, that is, similar to a layered cake, with protein and crystals layered and alternating, just like they do in the mother-of-pearl shiny inside of mollusk shells, or the surface of jewelry pearls. Using other proteins we showed that proteins are occluded in model biominerals, and permanently disorder the calcite crystal structure. This work led to the publication of 3 major articles in (Langmuir 2007, JACS 2010, JACS 2010).

 

We studied the mechanism of transformation from amorphous to crystalline mineral phases in tooth enamel, sea urchin spicules and teeth, down to the nano-scale. The manuscript on tooth enamel, in collaboration with Elia Beniash, was published in J. Structural Biology, and was the cover story. The one on sea urchin spicule, in collaboration with Addadi and Weiner, was published in PNAS in 2008. The one on sea urchin teeth was published in JACS in 2009, and again on sea urchin spicules in PNAS 2010. All four articles are milestones in biomineralization, as they address the very fundamental mechanism of transformation from amorphous to mineral, which explains how biominerals can behave in diffraction and polarized-light microscopy like single crystals, yet exhibit amorphous character in spectroscopy. The amorphous precursor phases explain the complicated and curved morphologies of tooth enamel or sea urchin spicules, spines, and teeth. The sea urchin teeth, in particular, revealed that the mechanism of transformation is one of secondary nucleation. In this mechanism an already crystalline nanoparticle (~50 nm) imparts its crystallinity and crystal orientation to the immediately adjacent amorphous ones, hence crystallinity propagates through the previously assembled, anhydrous biomineral (JACS 2009). The nanoparticles are 100% space-filling in biominerals (Nanoscale 2011). We also understood how the sea urchin teeth self-sharpen with use. This work was published in Advanced Functional Materials, and was the cover story in February (AFM 2011).

Three graduate students participated in this work, one of whom, Rebecca A. Metzler, has now finished and is an assistant professor at Colgate University.

We involved minority undergraduate and graduate students in all the research, and presented the results to the general public at many outreach events in Madison, WI.
